Authors: Lin Zhu, Jie Song, Bao-Kai Cui, Jun Liang Zhou
Title:
Phylogeny and biogeography of genus Sanghuangporus
(Basidiomycota)
Keywords:
Hymenochaetaceae, Phylogeny, Biogeography, Molecular
clock, Sanghuangporus
Abstract:
Backgroud: ‘Sanghuang’ is a popular fungus used as a
Chinese traditional medicine, but little is known about its origin and
biogeography. The aim of this study was to characterize the molecular
relationships, origin and biogeographical distribution of
Sanghuangporus. We used multi-locus phylogenetic analyses to infer the
phylogenetic relationships. In addition, based on Bayesian evolutionary
analysis using sequences from the internal transcribed spacer (ITS),
nuclear large subunit rDNA (nrLSU), translation elongation factor 1-α
(EF1-α), and the largest and second largest subunits of RNA polymerase
II (RPB1 and RPB2), we used a fungus fossil-based approach to gain
insight into the evolution time of species in Sanghuangporus. Results:
Molecular dating strongly support that Sanghuangporus is monophyletic,
Tropicoporus is a sister to the rest of the Sanghuangporus species (MP =
100, BS = 100 and BPP = 1.00. Bayesian uncorrelated lognormal relaxed
molecular clock using BEAST and reconstructed ancestral areas inferred
that the maximum crown age of Sanghuangporus was approximately 30.85
million-years-ago (Mya); East Africa was likely to be its ancestral
area, dispersal and differentiation to other continents then occurred
during the late Middle Micocene and Pliocene. Conclusion: The ancestor
of Sanghuangporus probably immigrated from East Africa during the
Oligocene-Miocene bround via the expanded plants inhabited on
‘Gomphotherium Landbridge’. Six kinds of dispersal routes are propose,
including intercontinental dispersal events of three clades among East
Asia and East Africa, among East Asia and North Americas, and among East
Asia and Europe.
